name: DMARC Record Published
description: Having a DMARC record is essential for all websites to protect against email spoofing and phishing attacks. This improves email security and ensures that only authorized senders can use the domain.

name: Blacklist Analysis
description: Regular checks against blacklists help websites maintain their reputation and email deliverability. Being clear of blacklists ensures trustworthiness and reduces potential communication issues.

name: DNS Record Published
description: Properly configured DNS records indicate a well-maintained domain setup, which is critical for website functionality and secure communication.

name: TLS Support
description: TLS encryption secures data transmission, protecting user information and ensuring compliance with modern security standards. All websites should implement TLS for enhanced trust and security.

name: PTR Records and Reverse DNS
description: Correctly configured PTR records improve email deliverability and prevent emails from being flagged as spam. This is a good practice for maintaining domain credibility.

name: Regular Monitoring
description: Continuous monitoring of DNS, SMTP, and other configurations ensures issues are detected and resolved promptly, keeping the website secure and operational.

name: Implement Quarantine/Reject DMARC Policies
description: Enforcing strict DMARC policies prevents unauthorized email use, protecting users from phishing and domain spoofing.

name: Update and Maintain DNS Records
description: Accurate and up-to-date DNS records, including SPF, DKIM, and DMARC, ensure secure and efficient communication.

name: Use Secure Connections
description: HTTPS with TLS encryption protects data in transit, ensuring user privacy and website integrity.

name: Blacklist Resolution
description: Resolving blacklist issues promptly maintains a website's reputation and ensures uninterrupted email delivery.

name: SMTP Connect Failures
description: SMTP connection failures indicate potential network or configuration issues that can disrupt email communication. Investigate and resolve these problems promptly.

name: SMTP Reverse DNS Mismatch
description: Reverse DNS mismatches reduce email credibility, potentially causing emails to be marked as spam. Ensure accurate PTR records to avoid this issue.

name: Blacklist Inclusion
description: Being listed in blacklists can harm email deliverability and reputation. Investigate the cause and take corrective actions, such as resolving spam-related issues.

name: Open Relay Check
description: Open email relays can be exploited by spammers, leading to domain blacklisting. Ensure relays are secured to prevent unauthorized use.

name: DMARC Policy Not Enabled
description: A DMARC record without a quarantine or reject policy leaves a domain vulnerable to spoofing. Implement stricter policies to improve security.

name: Check Open Ports
description: Scanning open ports helps identify entry points that attackers might exploit. Best tools include Nmap and Nessus. Ensure only necessary ports are open. Unused or misconfigured ports can be a security risk.

name: Analyze Firewall Configuration
description: Evaluate the effectiveness of your firewall in filtering unauthorized access. Tools like Wireshark and Firewalld are useful. Misconfigured firewalls can expose the website to attacks.

name: Inspect DNS Records
description: Ensure DNS records (A, MX, TXT, etc.) are secure and not leaking sensitive data. DNSDumpster and MXToolbox are reliable tools. Misconfigured records can lead to DNS spoofing or subdomain takeover.

name: Perform Network Vulnerability Scans
description: Identify vulnerabilities in the network layer using tools like Nessus, OpenVAS, or Qualys. Outdated protocols or weak encryption can pose risks.

name: Check SSL/TLS Configuration
description: Ensure SSL/TLS certificates are properly configured and up-to-date. Use tools like SSL Labs. Weak or expired certificates can expose sensitive data.

name: Monitor Network Traffic
description: Analyze network traffic for unusual patterns using tools like Wireshark or Zeek. Excessive or anomalous traffic could indicate an attack.

name: Evaluate Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS)
description: Test IDS/IPS systems for their ability to detect and respond to threats. Tools like Snort or Suricata are valuable. Improperly tuned systems may generate false positives or miss threats.

name: Check for Secure Protocols
description: Ensure secure protocols like HTTPS, SFTP, and SSH are used instead of insecure ones like HTTP, FTP, or Telnet. Tools like SSLyze can help evaluate protocol security.

name: Identify Weak Password Policies
description: Assess password policies for strength, such as complexity and expiration requirements. Weak password policies increase the risk of brute force attacks.

name: Assess Third-Party Integrations
description: Examine third-party services and APIs for potential vulnerabilities. Tools like OWASP Dependency-Check are helpful. Vulnerable integrations can serve as a backdoor for attackers.

name: Perform Penetration Testing
description: Conduct simulated attacks to identify weaknesses. Tools like Metasploit or Burp Suite provide comprehensive penetration testing capabilities. Lack of regular testing leaves unknown vulnerabilities.

name: Monitor for Outdated Software
description: Check for outdated software, libraries, and plugins that may have known vulnerabilities. Tools like Dependency-Track and Snyk are useful. Outdated software is a common attack vector.

name: Validate Network Segmentation
description: Ensure that sensitive data is isolated within segmented network areas. Tools like SolarWinds Network Performance Monitor can assess segmentation effectiveness. Poor segmentation exposes sensitive data to unnecessary risk.

name: Check for Vulnerable IoT Devices
description: Analyze connected IoT devices for vulnerabilities. Tools like IoT Inspector can help. Unsecured IoT devices can act as entry points for attackers.

name: Network Requests
description: Lists the network requests that were made during page load.

name: Network Round Trip Times
description: Network round trip times (RTT) have a large impact on performance. If the RTT to an origin is high, it's an indication that servers closer to the user could improve performance.

name: Server Backend Latencies
description: Server latencies can impact web performance. If the server latency of an origin is high, it's an indication the server is overloaded or has poor backend performance.

name: Resources Summary
description: Aggregates all network requests and groups them by type.

name: DNS Lookup Time
description: Measures the time taken to resolve the domain name to an IP address. High DNS lookup times can indicate issues with the DNS provider or configuration.

name: TCP Connection Time
description: Measures the time taken to establish a TCP connection with the server. High connection times can indicate network congestion or server load issues.

name: TLS Handshake Time
description: Measures the time taken to complete the TLS handshake process. High handshake times can indicate issues with the TLS configuration or server performance.

name: Time to First Byte (TTFB)
description: Measures the time from when the request is made until the first byte of the response is received. High TTFB can indicate server-side performance issues.

name: Content Download Time
description: Measures the time taken to download the content of the response. High download times can indicate network bandwidth limitations or large response sizes.

name: Redirect Time
description: Measures the time taken for HTTP redirects. High redirect times can indicate inefficient redirect chains.

name: Cache Performance
description: Evaluates the effectiveness of caching mechanisms by checking cache headers like 'Cache-Control' and 'ETag'. Poor cache performance can lead to unnecessary network requests and increased load times.

name: HTTP/2 Utilization
description: Checks if HTTP/2 is being used for network requests. HTTP/2 offers performance improvements over HTTP/1.1 by allowing multiplexed streams and header compression.

name: Cookie Security
description: Ensures that cookies are marked with Secure, HttpOnly, and SameSite attributes to enhance security and reduce the risk of attacks.

name: API Response Times
description: Measures the response times for API endpoints accessed during page load. High response times can indicate backend performance issues.

name: Network Payload Sizes
description: Analyzes the sizes of network payloads. Large payloads can increase load times and affect performance, especially on slower networks.
